comments.commentBody: Watch them change their minds next week and suggest the very opposite!

So... why not prepare food for yourself?
No time? Then an apple and a handful of nuts is the ultimate in convenience fast food. Easy!
The body does not need carbs to function. What do you think eskimos (used to) eat?
Hear! Hear!

Live by the media, die by the media.  Mr. Christie became a media darling a few years ago when a few reporters and commentators mistook his public bullying and obnoxiousness for charisma and leadership.  But, the bloom has long since worn off the rose.  In the last year or so, reporters have caught wise to reality: obnoxious bullying isn't leadership, it's just bullying.  And, so, Mr. Christie is no longer a media darling and his star has faded.  Only he seems to be unaware of it, so far.  But reality is going to sink in rather quickly as donors and pundits move on to other golden boys.  I doubt seriously whether Mr. Christie will even announce that he is a candidate.

Great post. The mental health industry has a similar story -- it has been dominated by unscientific quackery that has caused people more harm than good. (For example, psychotherapists have been recommending analyzing one's problems in depth, but research coming out now is showing that rumination and too much self-reflection causes depression and anxiety, and the thing people can do to feel better is to turn their attention to people/things/ideas/experiences outside themselves.) There are many parallels, but the nutrition industry regulators seem far ahead of the mental health industry in terms of recognizing the need for transparency and robust scientific evidence. New York Times, please do a story on this, as well. Thanks!

Those CEOs are making MILLIONS.  They can't get rich being president.  They don't care about the country.  The White House isn't as classy as where they live.  AND they'd have to explain themselves and be accountable.

There has been a lot of mention of bridgegate. However, don't forget about Christie traveling to Dallas to root for the Cowboys.

That act, while de minimis, just corroborated what a puerile, improvident dunce Christie really is. Most adults realize that football is an amusement, and not worth a lather. Nevertheless, there is a big downside to taking sides against the Giants/Eagles/Jets.

His bright sweater might as well been a placard stating, "I believe in the Easter Bunny."
The rest of the country is coming to know what many of us in New Jersey knew about him as early as his first campaign for governor.  He is toast.
Are you asking for the gravely ill patient to have compassion for the young doctor?

Once Messers H-P left the company and the other engineers were consigned to the sidelines, HPs fate was sealed.   Carly had a board fight with one of the founders and she won, the engineering segment of HP was relegated to second place and the acquistion of Compaq was both ignorant and destructive.  Carly walked away with a $60 million-plus goden parachute.  HP was once the prenier IT/engineering firm in Palo Alto, no more.   Their engineering equipment was top notch.   HP has clearly lost its way and I do not see Meg turning this disaster around either.

I'm always amazed at people's different perspectives.  There is a movement afoot in the US to denigrate & eliminate government "interference." (although I don't know how all those politicians would earn a living, but I digress). Yet there are commentors here blaming government dietary guidelines for obesity?? Let's face it the only people who pay attention to gov't dietary guidelines are those who run school lunch programs and we all remember how well replacing french fries with apples went.  Living in a decidedly Ist world country we have to get a grip, read the label, learn how to cook broccoli, take personal responsibility, and most importantly learn some restraint & enjoy!

Sugar in large w quantities is definitely an enemy, but the sweeteners are very suspect. They also continue to promote a "sweet tooth" - whether that alone is a  added problem in addictive like ingestion of sweet drinks, and artificially sweetened foods, we may later learn.

Adele Hite, a registered dietitian and spokeswoman for the nonprofit Healthy Nation Coalition, said that in the decades since their inception, the guidelines had played a direct role in the explosion of obesity and chronic disease by steering people away from nutritious whole foods like meat, eggs and butter.

It's worse than that. HFCS is much worse than sugar. They push it in the american public. By lambasting sugar they move people to diet drinks which are far worse. It is the government that is poisoning us with a thousand chemicals but never real food.

Don't blame *science* on this one Charlie B.

Yes, there is much yet to discover about how we absorb this or that, and how that affects us, but mostly we need to consider the agenda -- the one that all of these folks claim not to have -- and how it structurally determines their tentative conclusions about our diet.

Who in their right mind, for example, would *ever* believe anything (food pyramids, etc.) that comes out of the Dept of Agriculture?

Not the fault of science. It's the abuse of science.
Don't wait for things to change. Just stop buying packaged food.  No need for information.  Veggies, fruit, meat, plain dairy, grains.... no need for information because nothing is added.
He's not that charismatic.  He comes off as a blustery bully, even in personal TV appearances.  His "man of the people" act is growing old quick, and is no longer believable, if it ever was.

New Jersey has always been known for its' thug-like political culture, but starting with his tenure as US Attorney, when Christie's generosity to friends effectively forced the Bush Justice Department to impose new limits on handing out contracts to compatriots, Christie has set a new standard. He is enormously charismatic, but his record as governor - not simply the state's deteriorating fiscal condition, eroding infrastructure, insolvent pension system, and poor job growth, but all the contracts blatantly handed out to friends - never would have withstood scrutiny in a presidential general election. It would be better for the Democratic Party nationally if he weren't blowing up so early.
and what would be wrong  with that, like cholesterol there is little to no evidence that red meat"saturated fat"is anything but beneficial. follow the science.

and what recent study shows meat deleterious to your health?
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/behindtheheadlines/news/2014-03...
They have clues but, they don't want to bite the hand of Monsanto et al.
Is it not abundantly apparent these "experts" have not a clue?

Might any of the reduction in heart attacks attributed to this diet result from other things, such as less stress? The societies that practice this diet (Italian, Greek, Spanish) seem to be much more relaxed about life in general, less striving, than the more industrialized countries of the north.
As to the recommendation to eat more fish, I hope they are referring to farm raised fish, as we have already overfished the world's oceans to the point of destruction.

Just don't eat packaged products sold in the supermarket.  See?  That was easy.  Breakfast, soft boiled eggs, homemade bread, boiled rolled oats, milk. Lunch sandwich with homemade bread, maybe peanut butter (read the label get the kind that's just ground peanuts), fruit.  Snack on fruit.  Dinner cook up some meat, bake a potato, steam some fresh veggies.   Not a packaged item in it.

"...for the first time the panel recommended that Americans limit it to no more than 10 percent of daily calories..." While this is a step in the right direction, the World Health Organization recently lowered their daily sugar limit to 5 percent of daily calories.

Sugar is clearly the number one problem in the American diet, but beyond sugary drinks, avoiding it will be difficult for consumers. Over 70% of the packaged products sold in the supermarket contain added sugar, usually in the form of High Fructose Corn Syrup. Requiring daily sugar intake percentages on nutrition labels would be a good first step.

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
Say, how about someone cooks up a news story that deals with this issue: Christie in no way has the self control or temperament to be president of the United States. Would anyone want a loudmouth, angry bully to be our chief diplomat around the world? Who? Why?

If billionaires and others are willing to give him money, do they overlook his personal in your face style? If so, why?

Christie has gotten where he is by being loud and proud, his calling card. That's what has brought him attention. In an age of carefully manicured (in every way) politicians and in the aftermath of the phony, Mr. Smooth Mitt Romney, people are looking for something different. That different?

The nation might have turned to Christie in a time of dire financial crisis like the Bush** Great Recession which hit in 2008. Now, he's yesterday's news or maybe that's noise.

http://terryreport.com

**I call it the Bush recession because it happened on his watch. It is up to whoever is president, and his team, to avoid or try to avoid such disasters, although some of the seeds of the Great Recession clearly were planted during Clinton with the repeal of Glass-Steagall, which ended the separation of banks from investing.

After hugging Obama, Christie rounded up 38% of New Jersey voters for Romney, a fellow northeastern "moderate" Republican. For reasons that are too licentious for these pages, I really really like New Jersey, but let us get real. If 38% is the biggest boulder you can throw onto I-95, you ain't getting no where, Christie.
just an ideological twist on Mike Huckabee, maybe he'll get lucky and get a tv show out of this after Jersey folks wise up and throw him out in the next gubernatorial election
I haven't seen any indication that he cares about what people of his state care about, think or feel. Why would he start now?
I have been cutting carb and eaten more meat. Now, I think I should eat less meat and little more carb.
Agreed. We should also demand a separation of responsibility for diet recommendations and farm policy. The USDA has both today and it represents a conflict of interest, (our interest.)
Is it too much to ask that dietary recommendations be based on science instead of guesses?
